title: job security and good benefits if you can put up with the rest
pros: Job security in this industry is surprisingly decent if you are happy to work the same position forever. Health insurance was actually above average in my experience and the company contributed to HSAs. Decent 401k match. 10 days of PTO and 5 “floating” days standard yearly. But if you ask nicely in the hiring process, they may grant you an extra 5 days. You get an extra # of days every few years.
cons: Let me just say this reflects my experience as a former employee but does not necessarily reflect the current experience or that of every department. 1. Messy… Everyone was always stressed out and anxious, which evidently trickled down from the top. I saw seemingly very little strategy behind all the busy work which then produced little to no results. Fire drills constantly. You were expected to be “on call” 24/7. No one was interested in updating strategy to avoid falling behind competitors/trends as long as sr mgmt got their bonuses. if you made a small mistake on something you were trained on for 5 mins, you’d be chewed out and treated as if you just demolished the entire business. Was toxic at times. 2. Personalities were a whole other issue - felt very high school or reality TV at times and cliquey. Heard my fair share of inappropriate, sometimes racist, and body/appearance-shaming comments. Lots of gossip and things that should have been handled between the person and their manager in a private and professional manner. Some people did not know how to have hard conversations with the people they worked with and instead it turned into petty drama. Since it’s actually surprisingly hard to fire permanent employees at this company they will bully you until you quit. If you’re a contractor they will just fire you the same day. Neither of these were my own experience but behaviors I witnessed several times. 3. Raises and salaries were and are still not competitive with reality. My job title changed significantly but not on paper and mgmt or HR would not initiate an official title change or salary adjustment. No opportunity for growth until someone leaves, and even then you may be blocked from applying for an internal position. Whatever technology they use to determine salaries is stuck in 1990. Raises are capped at 2% and the bonuses negligible, even before taxes. the amount of work you will end up doing is worth double the pay for very little reward or recognition. During Covid, raises were capped at 1% and was not made up for the following year, while upper management that took pay “cuts” got it all back in retro pay. Either way, each “raise” you actually take a significant pay cut due to inflation.

title: My Opinion but Your Choice
pros: (Field work pov) You get to meet a lot of different people on your team and your customers. Depending on you or your team, tough days can easily roll off your shoulders with ease with the help of each other. Treat you customer with compassion (regardless of the situation) and you can make the most heated customer your best friend. Don't be shy to say hi! People can be very kind. The better you get to know the people you work with, the easier work becomes. As long as you are given respect and time to be trained, then you can easily grow quickly in the company. You'll learn a of new skill that you can apply in the future. Also , great way to connect on the business side of life. Lot of fun events. Make a lot of good friends. Forgive me, there are probably more pros, however I seem to be having an issues balancing them out with the cons.... That however, could be due to my own relationship with my job positions, and other experiences here.
cons: (Field work pov)They expect you to do more than humanly possible. A lot of jobs positions have been discontinued through out the years in a blink of an eye. This puts a lot more stress and problems on the ones that remain. Plenty of employees have been pushed to take care of other properties and their own. Now a lot of positions require you to do "hybrid" jobs. Not the kind that you come to work or stay home, hybrid. But the kind where you're stuck doing four job positions in one. Delegated right with a respectable team and your time, it could be possible to make it through. However, I would not doubt your mental and physical health rapidly decline due to the amount of stess. Always watch the ones who gossip. Especially, if they are senior workers that are know around the company. If you're a new employee and they don't like you, you might as well quit. They will not let you get ahead for a second. No matter how good you are. They'll take away any confidence you had in yourself. It is not below them to bully you into quitting or pushing others to fire you. They will pull any excuses to do so. I mean ANY. Because they worked there for so long, the company/team will let them get away with it. Unless, you have a strong / fair higher-up and supportive team that'll stop it beforeit gets worse. It's like highschool all over again, folks. When in a toxic environment, if your boss hasn't confronted you about a situation at work, and they write you up for the smallest things, leave! Most likely the are trying to fire you anyways, and they won't stop until you are gone. Oh, and they will tell your teammates of your work/personal unfortunate circumstances and then some. You'll know when you're not welcomed anymore. Even if they smile at you. Especially, if they leave their work space to go whisper something to another, and you're the only one else in the area. It could be their own personal issue. However, if you are experiencing anything from above, I wouldn't count on it. (Also, lower rank positions get pick on just as much. Doesn't matter how long they've been there.) As much as I hate to say it, depending on the location, the teams can be extremely toxic. So please be careful of your mental health. It can and will effect your physical health over time if not taken care of. Burn out is real, and some choose to ignore the signs of their employees. Just assume they already don't trust you, and get a doctor's note. Better safe that sorry. Because of everyone being so overwhelmed with their jobs already, you are not likely to get proper amount of training, and you'll need it. If, however, you have been in the same position and just need side notes than you'll probably be fine. Keep in mind, a lot of changes are happening, so you might not know the same programs. Good luck finding someone who does or has the time. I won't even discuss pay. Just keep in mind the work and time you put in. Oh and take your lunch away from work. Give yourself that mental break. You're going to need it. If you want a challenge, this is it. If you have a good team, in good health, mental "normal", multi tasker, works well under pressure, open minded to change, handle unhealthy amount of stress, confident, and ok with the possibility of your position being cut, then go right ahead. But that all depends on what you pursue, and the people you work around. Sometimes it doesn't matter how longer you work here. It could also be how far down the latter you are in the company.

title: Tenant Coordination - Do not expect this to be a positive career move, you will get no respect from upper management.

cons: Din't let the good salary entice you to take a position in Tenant Coordination. They lure you in with a good salary and give you time to increase your standard of living. Once they think you can't afford to quit (they do pay on the upper end of the scale and it makes leaving difficult), they will begin to tell you how terrible your work is, degrade you and try to reduce your self esteem (another tactic to keep you from leaving). You will ultimately feel trapped and hopeless. At that point, upper management can then get their jollies kicking you around. Think I'm joking??? Salary growth stalls almost immediately but you won't find that out until your first performance review. No matter how much you excel and contribute to the success of the department. T.C. Executives have favorite employees who benefit economically from the entire team's effort. If you are not one of those favorites, despite how much you excel and contribute, you will get little to no bonus or salary increase, not even basic cost of living while others who are favorites will get showered with rewards and accolades. Beware: Tenant Coordination Executives practice corporate bullying and encourage their management staff to do the same... and they do. Tenant Coordinators do not coordinate tenants, they are upper management's crash test dummies. Upper management will do their best to make you crash and then call you a dummy. Remember, HR is a department that exists to protect the company, not the employees. HR will make that very apparent, if you ever go to them with an issue.

If you like filing for days at a time because no one knows how to take care of their own things, then you'll probably like this job You'll go through your vacation/sick/pto in no time because you'll probably will get some stress related illness and would need to go see a doctor to get better.

title: Really listen to what they say & pay attn to what you see...

It is all about the bottom line here although they will portray it as being all about the customer and how that is what sustains brick and mortar in today's digital world, This is not a company that practices what they preach, they have great ideas that never seem to come to fruition once they see what it would cost...

The mix n mingles used to have really good catered food then went cheaper and cheaper and then they just stopped having most of them. xmas giveaways have been going down from years...from a heyday of giving away a FREE car and thousand dollar visa cards and big screen tvs to cheaper cheaper cheaper, and recent xmas party cut even more.

A branch director position can easily over power a mall manager’s decisions. Simon employees tend to treat contracted workers (Cleaning crew, security, etc.) really disrespectfully. No one listens to those lower than an assistant director position; you’re essentially ignored. The training is not sufficient enough. You’re expected pick up tasks right off the bat. title: Brutal Employment Experience
pros: Good resume builder as they are very respected in the industry, for younger people good job security. The people who work there are for the most part good hardworking people. Decent benefits.
cons: Too many to list. The majors are horrible training programs and mentoring, poor salaries compared with market, miserable company culture (one section of the office know as 'cul de sac where dreams go to die'), extreme nepotism that doesn't reward hard work. There is a philosophy among middle and upper management that negative reinforcement produces the best results, and positive incentives nor feedback are valued. Management is rewarded for producing and not for managing, and most are more concerned in keeping their jobs so they hoard information. Decision making is so centralized that only the C-suite execs make any real decisions, and getting any real work requires a good set of pliers.

title: Ego-driven structure but not a complete waste
pros: Several people are hard workers, successful, caring, creative, team-oriented. Interesting projects and forward thinking approaches while kept in balance financially. Rewarding if you have a higher up position (but at a personal price).
cons: Unfortunately, several other people are also ego-driven monarchs and it seemed that was rewarded over hard work. Also meeting goals at all costs was top priority - so forget actually working as a team because you never know who's going to throw you under the proverbial bus. And, as others noted, there is zero family focus. You should not want kids or if you have kids hopefully they have graduated and moved out if you want to work for Simon. I worked most nights until 8 pm plus travel - which was fine since I knew that would be the case but not good if I wanted a life outside of work. Lotus Notes- seriously out-of-date....

title: Micro-management 101 - Look elsewhere and take the job only if a last resort
pros: Simon has some great assets in its portfolio

Zero work/life balance - it is completely unachievable with their model, I have been told it is expected that you do the work of 3+ people and they hold you accountable to doing it.

cons: Sorry, but my pros turned into cons. You work hard and long hours for not as much pay as the work deserves. The upper level jobs clearly have the higher salary to go with them. However, it hurts the morale of the average worker.

title: Marketing Administrator
pros: Looks good on a resume.
cons: EVERYTHING. This was the worst job I have ever had. There was a point where I was doing 3 peoples jobs at once for several months, with no training, and received no raise or any kind of bonus. The amount of work you do for such little pay was ridiculous. I was put down by management constantly and also shamed when it took me a while to do certain tasks that I was NEVER trained to do. If you asked a question they would roll their eyes and tell you to call another mall. Management only cared about themselves and had no interest or concern in teaching you anything or wanting you to succeed. They set you up for constant failure and make you feel worthless over a stupid entry-level job.

Our management team would slip out during the day to go shopping then wondered why our numbers dropped! Was sold on job as Monday-Friday 9am-5pm yet worked nearly every day until 8p and every weekend due to budget issues. HR was unsupportive when reported.

cons: Lack of planning (constantly in "emergency mode") Poor leadership Opportunity for growth (if you don't have a mentor; some managers don't care about your personal growth and future) No repressions for staff who slacks It is easy for good workers to get discouraged by unchanging systems and poor management Poor budgeting (over spending for no reason in some categories and under spending in others) makes some positions difficult When it comes down to employee safety or business, business always wins

cons: There were no challenges for my position. It's corporate so if that tells you anything.they don't really hire within, which is why I started working there in the first place I wanted to move up, and there is a ton of environmental waste, they just don't care

title: Lack of communication
pros: Nothing good to say this company and this mall is going down hill ever since they laid off everyone, that was their biggest mistake
cons: Ever since I became Marketing Admin I thought I would enjoy doing what I do but I was wrong, the management don't really care about you all they care about is $$ and gossiping which happens a lot here and at one point I overheard them talking about me, I'm not fully trained for my position and everytime they give me something they don't show me how to do it and it's always something I don't know what it is and they tell me to call another mall to have them help me train, I'm never in my office cause I work from the Admin desk and sell giftcards with no raise or anything, This is unacceptable I worked so hard to get this job and now I'm regretting it, this company isn't worth it

cons: Good luck at making anywhere from the average to maximum for your given position. There is a chart for every position with the given wage range. The property is limited on what they can pay based on the budget which is not correlated to the wage range. Training for new hires is very limited at best. Its a sink or swim atmosphere.

title: Marketing Director

cons: The company only cares about the bottom line and getting the most money from tenants, advertisers, etc. Doesn't care about field employees (although Mall Managers are treated slightly better). No work life balance. Redundant reports that the your managers never seem to read. If you are lucky enough to have a manager who cares or speaks up and questions, don't get attached because they'll be gone within a few months.

title: Low pay and mediocre benefits
pros: They have a beautiful new office downtown with a very nice gym. Nice people.
cons: Pay is not very competitive, average annual raises are 3%, no bonuses until management level, no tuition reimbursement and you pay extra if you add a spouse to your company sponsored insurance policy if they are eligible for one under their own employer. It's a significant amount...hundreds of dollars extra per month. 401k vesting is not 100% until you are with the company 7 years. You start off with zero paid time off. After the first year, you earn 2 weeks. After 5 years you earn a 3rd week and after 20 years you earn a 4th week. Never more than 4 weeks allowable. No carryover is allowed. No hybrid, no work from home and no part time allowed.

title: DO NOT ACCEPT!
pros: The only pro I take away from working for Simon was the experience and what warning signs to look for from an employer. I hate I wasted 3 years on this place.
cons: Unless you enjoy being stabbed in the back by a company and its employees, then do not work for Simon Proeprty Group. If you are an honest employee with solid morals, again, do not work here. The employees that lie, chest and steal are the ones they promote to higher positions. I had a lady from HR in Indianapolis actually tell me the only reason I was hired was because I had a friend within the company. Considering I interviewed with a completely different person her comment holds no validity. I met my goals and the employees I managed/mentored were promoted within the company so how did that not speak for itself.

title: Catch up

cons: There is a reason nobody in the world uses LotusNotes for email - it's awful. IT is horrible, in general. Takes days to get a reply to a ticket for a simple issue. No recycling anywhere in the building. Everyone uses styrofoam cups for the bad coffee in the kitchen and paper plates. No flexibility to work from home or remote. Cover pages print with every single print job which is a huge waste of paper.

title: Disrespectful Bosses Who Are Un Fit For There Titles

cons: Managers don't seem to having any training in how to deal with people. Completely in fear on losing my job every minute of every day for something stupid. Constant anxiety while working. Never a nice thing said about your work. Only negative feedback always. Managers are more worried about there bonus then the property, and don't spend money and it shows. Managers like to use workers as scapegoats when they mess up, they blame you for their mistakes.

title: Great company
