cons: I wouldn't necessarily say that there are many cons, as I can see why the company do what they do, but oftentimes you can be caught between doing the right thing and following the book by the rules, which can cause misunderstandings amongst management.

title: Marketing Intern
pros: Was given the opportunity to take charge of different projects and get involved in the planning and distribution process of signage, social media, and organizing events. Office employees become like family, you get to make many contacts and connections with organizations and retail tenants, you are included in meetings, conference calls, in-mall and external activities. You learn a lot about different marketing strategies.
cons: Top management is way too over their heads and can be too authoritative and demanding, they lack communication with employees, expect you to be as immersed and addicted with work like them telling you this is "the real world", many do not know how to prioritize and give the interns busy work and meaningless tasks.

title: HR doesn't care about harassment
pros: There's not much to say here. Certain places allow discounts?
cons: My coworkers often had complaints against them from customers. They would call people homosexuals in a derogatory fashion, yell expletives at customers, even laugh at them if they hurt themselves. This was all documented. We received angry letters from the higher ups often but nobody seemed to care. Because of this toxic environment, many people who joined the company would leave shortly after being hired. With some quitting during their shift Not to mention the building being in disrepair. The higher ups didn't deem it necessary to fix the leaks that would sometimes flood certain stores during storms. Or the faulty wiring that caused the speaker system to screech at random intervals or even catch on fire once or even twice a year. This is a shady company, your time and skills would be better put to use elsewhere.

title: Marketing Assistant
pros: I really did love my co-workers. We were an amazing team and I always felt comfortable with them despite our age differences. I also enjoyed being in charge of social media, though they control it a certain way because of the brand image. Opportunities for advancement if you don't mind stabbing a few backs along the way.
cons: Simon is a company that's all about the cold, corporate structure. I've seen good, hardworking people demoted because old employees that are still friends with higher-ups on the inside want their job back. Another guy spent 40 years at the company, and was fired 2 years before his retirement so that they could consolidate his position into another employee's job, who they were no doubt paying less. They give you a crap load of work for crap pay, and you never get recognized for it. A company that has no compassion for it's employees, is a company that isn't going anywhere, and it's one I'm glad I don't work for anymore.

title: The perfect example of corporate greed
pros: Really great benefits, full accessibility to PTO beginning first day of hire you do not have to accrue it. Top to bottom health benefits, employer contribution to HSA account, 401k.
cons: If you enjoy your family, holidays, or not being on your work phone morning to night on your days off then this isn’t the job for you. It is another example of corporate employees having no concept of what actually goes on within the field teams and their day to day work. Most positions do not have the ability to work remotely and you can kiss having time off for Thanksgiving, Christmas, or any other holiday goodbye with your family. Definitely a better fitting job for those without a family. Expect the pay to be incomparable to what it actually costs to live.

title: Director of Marketing and Business Development - MILLS
pros: A cell phone was offered as a benefit with unlimited access to data and usage so you could work 24/7.
cons: They do not hire employees to be strategic thinkers, they hire people and hand cuff them to their desk and do not allow them to do their jobs. You are simply put, an "implementer". This company micro-manages to a degree I have never experienced. During the course of 2 years the turn over of marketing directors was 10 out of 15 properties. The marketing leadership (i.e. VPM) rules as a dictator, one of the worst supervisors I have ever had.

title: Great company.. Wonderful pay and benefits.
pros: Large company. Hasn't downsized or been badly affected by the economy. Doing very well in the stock market. They treat their full-time employees well. Compensation and benefits are great.
cons: I work hard and my job is never compete. My boss is very difficult to work for. Having to meet last years sales goals is hard but my goals increase every year. I love the company I work for but feel I cannot transfer to a different position since I do not have a higher education than a GED. I have no way to attend college or even night classes since I am on call all the time I am salary and work well over 50 hours a week.

title: While the company is an industry leader, management cares only about the bottom line and not the people that make it all
pros: SPG owns and operates many of the nations top retail destinations. They are truly an innovative industry leader. David Simon has an excellent understanding of Wall Street. The company is financially solid.
cons: You are expected to work long hours and put the job ahead of family or personal pursuits. There is no work life balance. Upper management leads by intimidation tactics. Your job is always in jeopardy.

title: Great opportunity for Growth
pros: This is the largest REIT so the opportunity for growth is almost endless if you are will to travel or relocate. They do try and show appreciation for their staff by celebrating milestone anniversaries, holidays and birthdays for each employee.
cons: Since this company is so large employees can get "lost" and become a number. They have regional management but sometimes it can feel like high school where as if you are not in the "in" crowd you will feel it. The hours are crazy sometimes but it is retail and you should know that already going in.

title: Cliques and nepotism run rampant
pros: You can learn alot and get good industry experience. Many companies are familiar with the Simon name and brand which looks good on your resume.
cons: Unfortunately, being a reliable and hard worker will not get you far in this company. They like to promote from within but only the specific candidates who have connections and who management has already secretly been preening to take over coveted spots. Basically they already know who they will hire before they even post the position. Most managers are morons. Office cliques are strong and made up of adults who are stunted adolescents and don’t know how to act professionally,

title: You are disposable ...unless they can't find anyone to take your job
pros: Good résumé builder; looks especially good to competitors. Opportunities to transfer to other Simon Malls at their expense. However you have to pay some of it back if you leave in less than a year.
cons: If you're not one of the RVP's favorites don't expect to advance. Money driver. If you do well all they say is "Great. Now make us more money." Frowned upon if you ask for work life balance.

title: Terrible work environment and even worse corporately
pros: Good processes and great way to learn what you DON'T ever want in an employer
cons: Too many to list, but short list is work environment is terrible, culture is almost cult like, they even refer to "Simonizing" you. If you are a robot and don't have any skills, they will teach you to do just what they want, don't think, don't act just work, work, work and work until you die. It is similar to a work camp. I like to tell people for a Million Dollars cash I would not work a single day again for Simon. I promise you.

title: Business Development Folks: Keep on looking for another opportunity.
pros: The company seems fairly stable.
cons: Poor on-boarding program - it is a sink or swim situation. Payment plan is based on budgets. Hitting your budget is next to impossible the way they have their goals set up. While budgets will be increased yearly to meet corporates >10% growth demands, it is almost impossible to make those numbers based on the advertising assets that are now available. The office I was in was predominately professional. However, there were one or two individuals that really brought down the office culture and made work horrible for most.

title: There are better places to work
pros: Usually not demanding hours Work can be interesting
cons: CIO/CTO is a micromanager and doesn't let his key technical employees make decisions without his approval (they hired people like me to make technical decisions) Very poor communication from the company in general and from mid-level managers. My manager never gets our team together to communicate is yearly objectives (how can I help him if I don' t know what he's on the hook for?) and to help build teamwork among his team. The only way I know what others are working on is via small talk or if we 're working on the same project.

title: I have been working for Simon Property Group for 2 years now as a Guest Service Rep.
pros: The Guest Service Representative boss is very nice, and will work around your schedule the best he can. They also work with college student very well. The coworkers are very nice, as well as the upper managers. You will meet a lot of nice and interesting people.
cons: They don't give you many hours, the most you can get is 24hrs and that's if you have been there longer than the other employees. The pay is minimum wage, even though you have a lot of responsibility and if you mess up you get written up right away.

title: Simon offers growth however needs to be industry leader in benefits, pay and family worklife
pros: Growth potential, support, international recognition, good pay
cons: Not family friendly-Singles succeed further in the company, Antiquated systems, old and dated as a whole, On Lotus Notes for email! A lot of seperation among the portfolios, simonized mentality. Benefits are poor, especially vacation and PTO time benefits, behind those in the industry

title: Great, stable place to work
pros: Encouraging place to work where your superiors are truly invested in your personal and professional growth. I've felt that since I started with the company.
cons: The company is very large, so it is easy to feel like you are a big fish in a small pond. There are supervisors, then managers, then senior managers, then directors, then vice presidents, and on and on.

title: The Worst Company I've Worked For...
pros: I truly have no positive comments about working at Simon Property Group.
cons: Oh my I don't even know where to begin! I will say this please do not make my mistake and not fully take in all the reviews here on Glassdoor! I was so blinded by, "Oh I'm going to work for this enormous mall developer company" and it'll look great on my resume. Not to mention not all money is good money! Working for Simon Property Group is not worth your resume looking good or whatnot. All the negative reviews on here are speaking the truth!!!! All the comments about the extreme lack of training and support along with the working environments full of tension, rudeness, demeaning you, belittling you coming from the regional level and other field team members... ALL TRUE!! DO NOT WORK FOR SIMON PROPERTY GROUP!!!!

title: Worst place I’ve ever worked
pros: A lot of PTO and holidays
cons: I worked at a property in NorCal. My boss was atrocious and Simon really has no HR department to report terrible behavior to. They hire people in managerial positions with absolutely no experience to speak of and they in turn drive away actually qualified people. The pay is horrific and they seem to only give raises to people who already make a living wage. They occasionally do contests in which you win gift cards, but they include it as wages and tax you. The health insurance is terrible and is basically worthless. I’ve heard it’s only tolerable if you work in their corporate office, otherwise I’d stay away.

title: 1/10 experience. Would not recommend.
pros: Decent pay....which you could make at any other organization and save yourself a lot of stress.
cons: Worked as a Manager on the field team and it was the worst experience I have ever had. The company loves last minute fire-drills with insane due dates, lack of work life balance (trust me they would take your soul if you let them), and horrible management leading teams. If you sign on here, be prepared for a lackluster job that will take away all your time and happiness. The best thing I ever did was get out here and I haven't looked back since!

title: Micro management on every level
pros: Great experience and skill set builder. Only use this company as a stepping stone for your next position.
cons: You won’t just have one boss, you’ll have 3 or 4 or 5. Expect micro managing to happen from every level of the business. You will have calls set up with each person so they know what you’re working on. There’s zero trust for you to do your job. And when you are doing a great job, they will never tell you. You only get scolded when you can be doing something differently or better in their eyes. Also expect pay way below market. The amount of responsibilities will keep you busy, but it’s not worth the stress and the pay is definitely too low for everything they throw at you. It’s a terrible company to work for unless you’re using it to boost your career.

title: Had A Decent Run
pros: Everyday is a experience that is often met with new people to meet and new things to learn whether it be about the company, the mall or people in general. A busy day goes by fairly quickly as long as you keep a positive head, do the work and focus on the customer.
cons: The pay is a decent starting rate. However, for the actual work expected and the amount of people at my King of Prussia location, the pay rate should be more complimentary to the catering done by staff to Mall guests especially around the fast growing traffic of the holidays.

title: Work for any other mall management company, it will be 10x better.
pros: Relocation options, that covers it all
cons: Everything else is a con. Simply a pss poor operation that prides itself on working management 24/7, always on call, floods, ice, hurricaines, your life means nothing. Go to work or PAY the Simon Price all the time. It literally will make you ill.

title: WORST COMPANY TO WORK FOR
pros: There is nothing positive about being a slave for Simon. Salaried positions are exempt from over time and you only get a 2-4% raise annually.
cons: SEE ABOVE. Also, employees do not respect each other because of the way corporate's hierarchy is set up. The only way to success at this company is to point out the flaws in others. I know this is common in the corporate world, but at Simon, you are told almost every day that you are just a number and that your job can be done cheaper by anyone so they are constantly looking for a cheaper route.

title: Always changing environment
pros: - Fun generally upbeat environment (if you like malls) - Running a mall will keep you on your toes at all times!
cons: - Corporate teams micro manage the field teams way too closely - Not a place that really accepts or encourages you to voice your own opinions, what corporate says you do - You sometimes feel like you are always being watched and judged by corporate teams - Pay could be much better - Not much room for growth, no formal training to prepare you for promotions

title: Benefits
pros: Decent company benefits, can be used at a variety of different places. I don't really have any complaints about the benefits itself
cons: I had left Simon Property Group and typically you have your benefits for the rest of the month regardless of when you quit. Simon decided to end my benefits the day I quit, when I was suppose to have them throughout the month! It wasn't until i picked up a prescription when I found out they had canceled it! I went almost 3 weeks without benefits! What if something happened to me? I wouldn't have been covered.... Even after I quit this company still stresses me out!

title: Zero Loyalty, all about your last name
pros: Peer relationships Flexible/remote work options
cons: During my tenure with SPG, I saw MANY changes. Some were good and some were horrid. Simon is all about keeping its status as the largest REIT in the US. Senior leaders and execs, will step on anyone to get ahead. They have not handled COVID well. Leaving employees in limbo for months and eliminating an entire platform and leadership. It has become a “good old boy” network and it’s all about who you know or what your last name is.

title: Needs more growth opportunities
pros: Great health benefits, always had forty hours a week, enjoyable experience working with the general public, I had good mentorship. I made some good long term relationships.
cons: The monetary compensation was not sufficient, no benefits to help you with schooling, the schedule was erratic, I had to wear many hats that were not originally in my job description, I had no possibility for growth at my property.

title: Middle Management
pros: If you have the right boss the job can be enjoyable.
cons: They only care about the upper management and not the people who actually do the work! The company should bonus EVERY employee that they have not just the managers, they would never make bonus without the ENTIRE staff. Raises are also only big for the upper management, the workers get very little in way of raises. They need to take a hard look at their pay structure.

title: Decent job, but you'll need to figure it out on your own
pros: Competitive salary and benefits, with an opportunity for bonuses with hard work (and a little luck). This position has several different areas of focus, and I can choose how much time, and when, to spend on each. In my case, my superiors are knowledgeable and approachable.
cons: NO FORMAL TRAINING PROGRAM AT ALL. In an organization of this size, that's unacceptable. High turnover is a direct result of this. Outdated, slow computer system that relies on Lotus Notes (!), Microsoft Office 2002, and a million other programs that require a separate login, none of which can give you a complete picture all on their own. I have to look at three or four different reports to see what my guest services representatives sold the day before. Similar to any other job in the mall, there are easy times (summer) and times that are incredibly difficult and stressful (the Christmas season). There's not much middle ground.

title: Interesting
pros: SPG owns some of the best malls in the USA and is focusing on the top 20 Luxury Malls and putting the older assets into Washington Prime. The company and it's treatment of personnel lives and dies by the value of the stock, so know that going in. It's all about the Benjamins.
cons: SPG has been accused of unfair trade tactics many times in courts across the country and has been accused of over-leveraging older properties to invest in new malls then walking away from loans on older properties which creates urban blight and economic black holes. Not exactly good neighbors.

title: Great Company that works hard to care.
cons: idering they have so many employees, they try very hard to do things for those employees and make them feel wanted. Good healthcare benefits, company get-togethers, and highly invested in Simon Youth Foundation.

title: Maintenance
pros: The staff are great everyone gets along and works well together , the tenants are very respectful and the house keeping group does a great job keeping the place clean
cons: The management is awful . No parts inventory to speak of and when you need something the management screams budget and takes at least two weeks to get replacements . The property as a whole was built terribly half the electric is unidentifiable because of ongoing contractor error , as well as plumbing and roof issues for the same reasons . Operations will micromanage everything you do and expect you to do there job for them. The money they offer is not equal to the head ache they give , they will cut corners at every turn and do not value their employees. Take a job here at your own risk

title: Watch out! When times get bad, if you make more than others, you are the most expendable!
pros: Great people. Good attitudes. A willingness to help.
cons: Management does not care what happens to you. They will do anything to survive.

title: Worst Company To Work For
pros: 401K matching is all I can think of.
cons: The Marketing Directors feel that they are superior to everyone. The Guest Services Team is not appreciated. The Christmas bonus was petty. There is a lack of respect in the office and everyone back stabs each other in order to make themselves look better because they are in deep fear of losing their job at every minute due to the lack of training.

title: Pros and Cons
pros: Good benefits, especially for an entry level job. My office is very lax with schedules (no write-ups for tardiness or long lunches and time off requests are usually approved without question). Ability to move up in the company if you're willing to move.
cons: Low pay. No clear explanation of duties or training in my experience. A lot of higher level responsibility falls to lower level employees and there are different rules for different employees (especially between salary and hourly roles). Admin roles tend to be a little boring/tedious.

title: It is nothing but corporate politics and the constant game of who is the "Best"
pros: Company offers decent benefits A few good employees who actually work hard and care for others.
cons: Corporate is completely clueless of what actually goes on at a local level. Managers play constant games with hourly employees and have no regards for employee's well being unless it is beneficial to the company. Corporate constantly starting "new initiatives" and constantly pushing new implementation for the LOCAL Team to execute. Work overload is unbearable, and always more work being pushed on. Constant fear of making mistakes, the Simon culture is very cut throat. You are basically at the mercy of your managers if you are well liked you get to move up, even if you are clueless at your job. Issues are constantly pushed under the rug and if you think for a second you can rely on HR to assist in mediating or taking action to fix major ethic issues you are absolutely wrong. The most that will happen is the person you called about will know it was actually you who made the call... awkward much? Company has hundreds of polices and procedures yet rules are constantly being bent to fit the needs of Managers. No training with Simon you are basically fed to the wolves, if you are clever you will stay at float long enough to survive.

title: Old School
pros: Working for a Fortune 500 company could be a good stepping stone. The benefits are ok.
cons: It’s seems as though being rude to each other is encouraged. Their processes are antiquated because they don’t want to spend any money. Before the pandemic, my boss had never once taken me or the team to lunch. Not even on my first day. Since the pandemic, HR hasn’t communicated at all except for a couple emails that detailed the offices cleaning procedures and the temperature taking process so that you come to work. If you don’t come to work, you are shamed. Everyone is in constant fear of loosing their jobs so they come to work sick anyways. All the departments are completely siloed having no idea that the other department re-enters all the same data into another system. They still print everything and have giant broken Excel spreadsheets with very few people who even understand them. They don’t care about their employees at all. Raises are barely cost of living if you are lucky. They didn’t even try to have a virtual Christmas party instead they emailed at the end of the day before Christmas Eve to tell everyone they could take Christmas Eve off knowing that most people had either already used that day as a vacation day or didn’t prepare to take the day so they still had to come to work anyways. But still the nicest thing they have done since I’ve been there. David Simon has never physically addressed the company since I’ve been there. I’ve never seen the man. Not even virtually. He sends an email after earnings calls, that’s it. Everyone seems to be deathly afraid of him.

title: If they only knew
pros: Location, parking, good properties in portfolio and hardworking people in many segments. Company went through down turn better than most.
cons: All work in fear of CEO. It is run as his personal company and bully play pen. Very immature, degrading, with very bad manners. A very spoiled and unenlightened Napolean. Most are very happy he is gone to NY. Maybe some of the screaming and little bully boy name calling will stop. Work with very old fashioned technology. The IT sophistication is very low except when it comes to shutting down what programs can be used. Operating on out of date browsers and software. Company is full of control freaks.

title: I am not sure how a company could be run worse than SPG
pros: Flex hours (I have to write 5 words for pros, but I don't have enough pros to fill the requirement, so that is what this is)
cons: Pay Vacations Sick time Upper management Field employees are disposable

title: Field - Disconnected Company
pros: Enjoyed my immediate co-workers Enjoyed the day to day aspects of my job & dealing with store management
cons: Company is completely disconnected from the field. The left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing so the corporate office inundates the field with unnecessary reports & keeps such a tight rein on what the field offices are able to do that the field positions are essentially paper pushers. The computer programs are antiquated to say the least, Lotus Notes, really?!?! The CEO is so concerned about his $175 million dollar salary he doesn't care about his employees in the slightest.

title: Run away as fast as you can!
pros: Good Benefits Comparable Market Pay Very good at recognizing personal time - not many after-hours calls or emails
cons: SO MANY! Training - there is absolutely no on-boarding or training. If you haven’t done this job at a competitor previously, you are screwed because one half-day of “training” will get you nowhere. I.T. - Unless things have changed recently, they were still using LotusNotes as of last year. LotusNotes!! Not to mention, we were salespeople that were expected to be on the road, but they were not inclined to give their talent laptops. You couldn’t have a meeting off-site and pull up a lease plan, LOD, etc. It was a “security” concern. Management - What can you say about a company that laid off and furloughed thousands of people only two weeks into the Pandemic while continuing to save old retail business models to ensure their malls appeared “full”? Nothing. It’s a horrible example of corporate motivation. Mom & Pops and millions of small businesses across the country, were fighting to keep their staff on-board during this horrible time - yet, the real estate company with the best balance sheet of record, did not hesitate to show thousands of people the door only TWO WEEKS IN! That tells you all you need to know. Ruthless. All about the money. So many people that had worked for them for 15-25 years, were axed at the very first moment of a worldwide crises. Culture - No gatherings, no team outings. There was not one company-wide conference call - not even during the mall shutdowns to address rumors and/or worries. There was no team-building. Bottom line - If you need a job and want to make decent money and like working alone, knowing they will get rid of you in a heartbeat - then this is your place. Otherwise, run away as fast as you can. There are so many better companies out there where you can do this job.

title: Very underpaid position
pros: You can learn about customer service. Somewhat flexible schedule. Clear processes to follow
cons: The hourly rate is extremely low for the type of work and the expectations management has of the position.

title: The Best and The Worst
pros: Tremendous opportunity to grow with great income potential
cons: Lack of work / life balance; too accountable to the investors and too little concern for the merchants.

title: Exciting during the holidays, not much to do during dead times
pros: Always something new happening in the mall, get to interact with hundreds of different people, main point of contact for the mall, slight bonus pay for dry cleaning
cons: Often times during the mornings and after holidays there isn't much to do and you just stand around, can't leave your booth without someone from security coming up there and watching it for you

title: Poor upper management and employee development.
pros: The company did pay for medical insurance at that time, I do not know if they still do. The u8niform choices were not as bad as some companies that I've worked for.
cons: The mall was so poorly managed and physically upkept that tenants were pulling out of their leases left and right. It was impossible to make corporate set goals to sell mall gift certificates in a dying mall! Upper management worked banker's hours and had no idea what really went on nights and weekends at the mall.

title: Guest Services Representative
pros: Fun job meeting people and tourists of great diversity. Pretty easy job. Good experience working for a fortune 500
cons: Corporate rigidness Terrible black tie black suit outfit Typical retail sales asking for emails to customers who just want to know where a store is Mall offices lacks freedom or creativity

title: Well founded leadership, creme of the crop developers
pros: Innovative, well-adapted with smart leaders. They really know what they are doing and would be concerned a well-oiled machine in my book.
cons: Ownership likes to yell a lot. I could hear them a floor below. Although just an intern, was pretty surprised about how they let me in on a lot of projects and development.

title: Exceptional career growth opportunities. Restructured HR department in last 2 years and it has done wonders for employees. Great company to work for.
pros: If you are willing to work you can grow quickly in the company, but you have to be willing to move/relocate.
cons: Challenging to max out bonus opportunities as there are many things that go into the annual calculation.

title: Guest Services Representative
pros: Working with people, work get togethers outside of work, sales bonuses during holidays, pleasant customers (most of the time)
cons: Dealing with harsh and unreasonable management and marketing director, being given just under 40 hours a week so as not to be considered full time with benefits, and just not be professional when dealing with issues that arise. Conflict was never taken care of head on. To say the management is unorganized is an understatement.

title: Okay Place to Work
pros: Benefits package is pretty good for young adult Environment was okay to work in Decent amount of vacation and sick days Others in the company very helpful and nice to talk to when starting
cons: Still hourly pay for a full time position Position was really several positions rolled into one No real training, just kind of thrown into it

title: A number on a spreadsheet.
pros: Working in a mall was its own perk. The events, activations and media work was exciting. The network you build with store managers/ owners was very rewarding
cons: Not competitively paid Some of the bonus goals are based on things outside of your control and often unattainable. Zero work life balance after November 1st through the end of the year. several years I had only 2 days off in two months. Poor communication between corporate and field. The SBV department gets away with verbally abusing field employees when they have made an error with a deal they negotiated. Many upper level employees feel emboldened to literally scream and swear at field employees. Poor budgeting. anytime there are budget cuts they cut maintenance and housekeeping first but expect the same level of cleanliness/ visual appeal of the properties. I worked for Simon for 6 years. Several of my ideas became best practices across the company. After being furloughed 4 months during the pandemic. I was brought back, transferred to a property 45 miles from my home and tasked with director level responsibilities without the title or pay increase. When the transfer was revealed to me I told my regional how far it was from my home and how that would heavily affect not only my gas mileage but the time of my commute. After a month I let her know that it was taking me over an hour and a half every day and that I was having to fill up my gas tank more than twice as often. I never received a response to that email or the two follow ups. After 6 years as a very dedicated, productive and successful employee that was the final straw.

title: Worst Company
pros: Matching 401K, I can't think of any other pros.
cons: Poor management, unrealistic expectations, little pay, heavy workload, impossible deadlines. You are on your own. Corporate, HR and anyone in management will not stick up for you. You will always be in the wrong. Two positions were eliminated and I was expected to take on the extra work and then written up because I couldn't meet the deadlines. While my boss got a promotion with the money saved from eliminating these positions. This is the worst company and manager I have ever worked for. Very low morale in the office. DO NOT work for Simon.

title: Unarmed Security Officer
pros: Some of the pros that exist working at Tampa Premium Outlets are shift choices (Alpha, Bravo, and Charlie), customers service oriented, uniforms requirements, and leadership skills development.
cons: The Cons of working at Tampa Premium Outlets Security are scarce promotion options, rate of pay as an officer, division caused by miscommunication, completing jobs that are expected to be completed by other departments.

title: Guest Services Manager
pros: Decent pay, excellent bonus potential, competitive benefits, autonomy on the job
cons: No training, completely outdated computer systems, HR is aware of major policy violations and won't do anything about them. My particular property follows no rules and field management here will fire you if you report them since HR won't keep complains anonymous.

title: Local Leasing Rep
pros: Being able to see the latest in retail trends and working closely with other field reps in other territories made working the long hours tolerable. This job was interesting and creative. I was proud to work for this company for over 12 years.
cons: The company really only cares about the bottom line. "How much money can you squeeze from your tenants before they have to leave?" Management can be clique-ish and sometimes backstabbing. It really depends on how well you are meeting your numbers and if you kiss butt.

title: All about the #'s and not about the people
pros: Simon has really strong people and I learned a lot from my co-workers.
cons: They do not value their employees and they seem to enjoy belittling the people in the field.

title: Make the most out of it
pros: You will always be busy - best place to work if you are going thru a break up or in need of a serious challenge. Good place to learn about commercial real estate
cons: Very poor training - you must be able to be resourceful and hit the ground running on learning ALL policies and procedures. Work culture is all about work with very little to no work life balance.

title: Opportunities for growth, none for pay
pros: Growth within the company, opportunities to participate in events, chances to meet executives
cons: Very low pay - primarily in entry level roles with a huge jump in salary for the next level. Effort, willingness to take on tasks outside of the job description, and exceeding expectations are not acknowledged or rewarded.

title: Operations Director
pros: They like to promote from within. You can easily transfer to multiple locations. They have malls all over the US. They offer many opportunity for advancement. Professional work environment.
cons: I had to do too much paperwork. It's difficult to let go of bad hires. Weather issues create long hours.

title: Lots of work, little pay
pros: People working with are good people. Nice offices, amenities some companies do not offer.
cons: Lots of work, low pay no recognition, unless your top management. Marketing in this company is not necessary, anyone could do the high paying. bonus eligible position. Worker bees get paid poorly only the top management benefit with high salaries and bonus.

title: Disappointed in the c onnection between mid//upper management and their direct reports.
pros: Decent benefits, good recognition in the business world.
cons: Poor pay structure, poor communication, antiquated computer programs - none of which communicate with each other, mind numbing amount of procedures and paperwork - many of which are extremely outdated, does not promote independent thinking.

title: Marketing Coordinator
pros: Great place to learn the business.
cons: No bonuses. Not much opportunity for growth even though programs are in place to encourage it there isn't much follow through for mentors programs.

title: Strong & Focused Company
pros: Benefits are good. With many locations you have room to grow and move. Financially driven is the mantra. Fast paced environment.
cons: Can have long days. Work load can become extreme almost over night. Some tasks that should take relatively little effort can drag on. On the job training is weak at best but you can read a policy on any topic.

title: Maintenance
pros: I can say that I can honestly not think of one positive reason for anyone with any fragment of intelligence and common sense would want to work for this company.
cons: Where should I start? Unreasonable goals, told to make the place look great without having any tools. Constantly asked to complete and fix things with bubblgum and duct tape..known as one the.biggest companies, and the cheapest...the more $$ saved equals bigger bonues for management. The best thing I could suggest would be to anyone looking to work for this company STAY AWAY!!!--

title: Working here was beneficial to my pocket and resume.
pros: Relatively High Starting Pay Rate, Freindly and Compassionate Managers, great holiday pay.
cons: Poor quality work from co-workers, VERY stressful work, and

title: Good intern experience, but wouldn't work there full time.
pros: Exposure to planning events and promotions, able to do things outside of the office, get close with the small office staff, given responsibility on projects.
cons: Low pay, appears to be hard to move up the ladder, corporate conference calls were meaningless and lasted 2+ hours, saw many employees get their jobs threatened as a ploy to get employees to act a certain way, company culture is cutthroat.

title: The honest truth (New York)
pros: Great team! Best team I will ever work with
cons: You will be underpaid compared to your counterparts at different companies. You will also be heavily micromanaged. Simon doesn’t change it ways so what was done however many years ago is still done to this day.

title: Great Company to Get a Foundation
pros: Great company to get a foundation at and to take the to another company - great training, tools and procedures in place
cons: You are worked nonstop. I worked 24/7, you were expected to respond quickly to everything. Often vacations and time off were looked down upon even though you use the time or lost the time.

title: Not going anywhere
pros: It's not a stressful job. Really relaxing and easy.
cons: Management doesn't care about GSRs, they never check on us but if something goes wrong they blame us. There are no proper training. Training is pretty much hands on with older guest service reps.

title: Concierge at an Outlet Mall
pros: Great group of staffs - felt like a little family. The job was easy and SLOW. If you like a fast paced environment where you can learn a lot, this is not for you. If you are looking for a part time where you can do homework on the job, this is it.
cons: Maybe it was just the particular location I was at but management was bad. No clear expectations. No communications between managers. Managers micromanaged and berated employees to feel superior.

title: Lacks strong company culture
pros: The position is not difficult at all. It’s very laid back and a great part time for a student or someone just looking to get out of the house.
cons: Management office at my property were cold towards GSRs. They lack a modern, inclusive company culture. Management office would often be decorated for small office parties and fun but GSRs were invited or encouraged to attend. Training is minimal and mostly led by senior GSRs, which creates a lot of inconsistency in processes.

title: Laid back environment
pros: Great benefits, great upward potential
cons: The department is very old fashioned.

title: 6 Months in the Marketing Dept. of Florida Mall
pros: Very defined work methods and goals. Clear direction from upper management. Free tickets to lots of events. Great opportunities to network. Overall a positive experience.
cons: May occasionally be tasked with monotonous data entry tasks as well as cold calling. Not allowed to significantly contribute which makes work often seem unimportant.

title: Torture
pros: Nice to have access to downtown in the summer months
cons: The level of abuse from the EVP level is absolutely horrific. Childish, mean, bullying egotistical sorts are the only ones that can make it. The culture revolves around of cycles of verbal abuse. Intense attacks followed by a sort of honeymoon period are the only treatment you will experience. Also, if you are a woman or minority, don't waste your time. This is an old boys club of rich, white entitled men with a few token examples of women and minorities they keep around. If you get a chance to interview here, DON'T. DO. IT.

title: Guest Services Representative
pros: Honestly, your success depends heavily on your boss's. If you have the opportunity to work with some amazing people it can be very beneficial for you. Very flexible with your schedule so if your a Mom, student, or looking for extra cash this is the job for you.
cons: Simon Property has very little room for advancement. They also don't train their staff properly, they will hire you and expect you to figure it out.

title: Great company, bad circumstances
pros: -Individual work load in a team environment -Provided training -Professional environment -Enjoyable people to work with -Various avenues for advancement
cons: -Can have very monotonous work some days -Enjoyment linked to managerial style (I started with a great supervisor, moved to a senior role with a supervisor known to have a micromanagement style, did not enjoy that) -During first COVID lockdown, we lost 1/3 of our staff and doubled our work load. Regular overtime required to not fall completely behind. -Lack of "culture", you came to work and thats about it

title: Most long-term employees are cutthroat and not team players although they preach teamwork
pros: Great relationships with tenants, work life balance is good depending on the mgmt team, opportunity to learn a lot more than just your job, and there is generally flexibility with scheduling.
cons: The lack of a proper training program with the amount of informational knowledge required to conform to the "Simon" way. Actual company values are not the greatest.

title: Simon Outlets
pros: Working for Simon is really great because you can get really good hours and good pay depending on the store, and it's extremely laid back
cons: You're not full time but can work up to 40 hours a week with no benefits, and even though you're owned by one company every single store is treated differently.

title: Run, Run Fast Away
pros: Great job if you like to be tied to your desk awaiting emails and completing reports that will be changed a million times and then never looked at.
cons: Regional Management is not in sync with corporate directive. You are on call 24/7 and expected to watch emails and take calls even when on vacation. If you have a younger family, expect to miss all of their games, activities, doctor appointments, etc. You can never complain or ask for help. If you ask for help, then you are weak and will need to be terminated. Budgets constantly cut, but they expect facility to run and look like a palace since their name is on it.

title: Field operations
pros: Fast paced enviroment; constant projects and management requests. Wear many hats. Work the weekend shift and take a day off during the week. Shop the sales. Retailers and customers are typically pleasant to work with.
cons: Fast paced enviroment; constant projects and management requests. Wear many hats. Small staffs to support expectations. Lots of reporting. Small budgets. Helicopter management.

title: Executive sales, accountant and mover
pros: The money was good ...but I was hired under a different owner.
cons: You do EVERYTHING. You are supposed to be planning marketing for the merchants - who pay your salary. Instead, you are selling advertising, managing budgets, setting up tables and chairs before events and then taking them down after, selling gift cards, etc. Management is completely disconnected from the field, and have no idea - or no concern - that the demands on their time are unreasonable.

title: Simon is dying
pros: My boss is really understanding and nice. She understands what a student working part time has to go through and how terrible the customers are around this area.
cons: This is a dying business. These crappy malls will not be around for much longer. They are going to eventually lose interest from customers and die put because they can't keep up. Some of these malls are so outdated and old the only people using them are heroine addicts looking for a place to shoot up

title: Culture of Fear. Archaic Technology. Undervalued People.
pros: Intelligent, friendly people for the most part. (The really good ones won't last here though.) Nice building.
cons: Lotus Notes. MS Office 2003. No training & development. High stress environment. Most people fear "the 14th floor" (aka upper management). Many employees I know feel overworked and under compensated. Employees are definitely undervalued. Toxic environment. Very little room for development & growth for most. Company values are a crock. HR is unresponsive and inefficient, so don't bother going that route for help. No work/life balance. You can build a much more fulfilling career elsewhere. Long story short-- just don't do it to yourself.

title: Terrible
pros: Flexible hours when they have enough staff. Great for student or retired individual.
cons: They never have enough staff. They are unable to keep customer service staff for very long due to uncompetitive pay. Pay is low and raises pathetic. Cooperate staff never friendly when visiting properties and seldom introduced themselves to the lowly customer service staff. Basically as a face representing Simon we were never treated with any respect. However if you make one minor mistake they will put you on probation. No positive reinforcement or incentives to stay for very long or do great work.

title: Terrible company to work for...
pros: Great place to start if college student needing a part time job.
cons: No room for growth. If a position comes up they hire from outside rather then promote from within. The expectations from management is ridiculous for compensation given. Very depressing place to work. We had 9 employees quit in a 2 month period due to upper management.

title: Zero work-life balance or appreciation for employees
pros: -Decent benefits -Office environment can be good if you are at the right mall with good management
cons: -Corporate office/upper management does not care about field employees and will fire anyone at any time -HR department only cares about company, not about individual employees -Most managers are abusive and controlling and take advantage of hard workers -Not enough pay for what is expected of employees

title: Do your research first
pros: 401k match up to 5%. Relaxed office Friendly coworkers for the most part
cons: The manager of my property does not know how to actually manage. There is a lot of deadlines and work requested without compensation. I know someone working two positions but getting compensated for only one. A lot of favoritism in the office as well. Unfortunately, it's not a team environment. Go against the majority and you'll be out.

title: Needs Improvement in Management
pros: There was a simple dress code for everyone to follow. Besides that, not much unfortunately.
cons: It was mandatory to read off a script when addressing customers. They didn't allow the space for freedom of speech. Management was always around and didn't have trust in the employees. During most times, there was not enough employees to help all the customers in line. The shifts were split into two, however there was not enough employees so finding someone to cover was difficult.

pros: The people I work under are very nice and care a lot about the employees. It's a great family like work atmosphere. Simon has a lot of corporate rules to follow, but theres a lot of information to help adjust.
cons: I don't think my training has been handled well. HR hasn't sent back my employee numbers and so I haven't been able to start my formal online training and I've already worked for two weeks.

title: Co-manager, Sales Associate
pros: They have a lot of great products that I have the benefit of using. I've used everything that the sell and everything really works.
cons: They only pay 8$ an hour, its also a family owned business so they are never really checking up on the store or caring at all.

title: Large Company, Lots of Layers
pros: Good salary, pretty good health benefits. Good 401k matching perks after minimal time of employment. If you are willing to relocate to move up, there are options because of the quantity of centers owned. Daily work life at the center level is decent if you have a good GM that serves as a filter.
cons: Long holiday/weekend hours for all center management staff plus you're "on call" 24/7, hard to juggle this with a young family. Too many layers of management and you have to get approvals on almost every little thing even though center mgt. is said to be empowered. Very heavy administrative load - the amount of paperwork and approvals necessary to do anything is ridiculous and inefficient. A few personalities above me were more concerned about their bottom line (read: bonus) than the well being of the center. I was not involved in the decision-making of hiring other managers at my own center but rather was just told her the choice was being put into place. When I needed help while short-staffed, those in the regional positions to do this hiring purposely stalled on interviewing and getting someone in place. At the same time, another regional was slow to respond to requests for help and when he did, the response I got was "the expectation is that you will just handle things until...." Too much paperwork for bidding, paying invoices, leases, pretty much anything you want to do. Constant pounding to cut costs even to the detriment of customer amenities (while pushing us to increase customer amenities - with no dedicated budget). Daily requests and emails to fill out corporate spreadsheets, surveys, reports, etc. We received so many that we got additional email reminders with due dates just so we could keep them straight. All of this took away from actually managing the center. So many policies and procedures that's it's difficult to hire qualified individuals and train them on everything because it's so overcomplicated. Marketing programs are sent to the centers to be executed, so there is very little creativity for mktg. directors onsite other than to sell, sell, sell and make more for the bottom line. They have too many cooks in the kitchen to be effective (ie: too many bosses giving them directions). Basically, the management job was overall just very frustrating. After being in management and serving as a filter for all the directives coming down to us from all directions at the regional and corporate levels, it just because exhausting. "The Funnel Effect" is what one staffer called it - everything above just needs one little thing but by the time those "one little things" funnel down to the center, it's a million little things we have to react to (surveys, spreadsheets, databases, etc.) and usually nothing comes of them.

title: Good Company to work for
pros: The company will take care of you if you are able to perform and show that you have the determination to take the company forward. Challenging but satisfying.
cons: There is limited growth potential. The reason behind the ceiling is that the company is very lean and structured in a way that will take a number of years to get to the next level.

title: Lots of opportunity if willing to move
pros: The medical benefits package is pretty good and the 401k match is decent. There is opportunity to move up if you're willing to move.
cons: The on-boarding process is non-existant. There doesn't seem to be much effort made as far as employee appreciation or retention.

title: If you want a work-life balance don't work here.
pros: It is a large company and provides the opportunity to work pretty much anywhere in the country you want. There are some gems that work for Simon, especially in the Southwest. If you are interested in property management or retail this is a great place to build experience and contacts.
cons: Simon does not care about their employees. This is reflected in a number of ways. One, there is minimal training programs in place to effectively equip employees to be successful in their respective roles. On this point I will give them some credit as they are starting to ramp up efforts in this area but they are sorely behind given their size and continued growth. It's typically a "throw you into the deep end" scenario and if you don't make it, tough, they'll find someone else who will. This sends an immediate message that you are not valued as they won't even take the time to make sure you have what you need to do the job. Two, there is no company support of a decent work life balance. Retail in it's very nature can be very demanding, especially during the holiday season. The message that gets to the field employees is typically get it done no matter the cost or get fired. I've seen tenured employees with many successes in previous years get fired or seriously demoted after one significant failure. Again, reinforcing the feeling that you are not valued as an employee and if you aren't perfect, don't apply. Three, the culture is very political and can get really nasty. If you're not is with the right people you can kiss your career opportunities goodbye. If you don't like playing theses games this company is not for you. At the end of the day, culture trickles down from the top. By all accounts and some personal experience the home office is a hot mess and top executives are some of the greediest, nastiest, self-important people out there. Unless attitudes change at the top, nothing will change throughout the company. All that is valued is making money at whatever cost and taking care of employees that work hard to make that happen is not a priority. Four, the company doesn't pay well (so more money will hit their bottom line). If your role exists in another industry, go there. Simon pays very low rates and expects crazy hours in the field. Overall I had a very poor experience with Simon and would not recommend this. There are plenty of companies out there that have found a way to be successful and take care of their employees. Simon will most likely never be one of those companies.

title: You’re able to gain a lot of experience but other than that, upper management and HR could care less about you
pros: Learn a lot about the industry.
cons: Workplace harassment happens far too often at Simon. HR is completely useless. This is the type of company that looks great externally or on paper, but internally is an absolute mess. They are beyond outdated as well.

title: Great company but could make some improvements
pros: The company is a great company to work for. They prefer to promote from within, the pay is good, and the culture for the most part is good.
cons: Some of the things they can work on are training, and teamwork. At times it felt everyone was on their own instead of working as a team. The lack of training also makes it hard for those people that move up the ladder.

title: Marketing Assistant
pros: Get to plan fun events, work with hard-working people.
cons: No room for growth, repetitive events and ridiculous sales goals. Pay is very low.

title: Marketing Administration
pros: 10 days PTO and 5 floating holidays.
cons: Everything. This company is so stingy. The pay is horrible. Their processes are horrible and not thought out ahead of time. They will cut your position and reformat your entire office dynamic without notice. They don’t care about their employees at all. You are just a number here. I have never left a company review, but this is bad enough that I need to. If you have other career opportunities, do not even consider this place.

title: Run Before it's Too Late
pros: Good Benefits Nice Offices Nice co-workers Energetic environment
cons: Staff attorneys function more like paralegals than as attorneys. The company promotes "fill in the blank" performance and does not encourage independent thinking or issue spotting. Redundancy in the computer system is a total waste of time, and attorneys spend more time typing in reports than in performing work on documents.

title: Administrative Assistant II
pros: The mall is a great atmosphere and wonderful environment with constant striving shopping places for customers to enjoy. Discount is offered to all employees within the mall at the different shopping stores within the complex.
cons: The Pay is low for the work your required to accomplish. Benefits are not as great as they say.

title: Guest Services Representative
pros: Flexible with work-life-school schedule Great entry-level position for improving customer service skills Many opportunities exist to move throughout the company
cons: Script for customer sales interaction requires GSR to ask the customer too many questions Not enough resources to manage difficult customers

title: Unethical Management
pros: Great benefits. If you can do well here, you can do well most places.
cons: No oversight of management and allowing unethical treatment of employees. Poor complaint process for when an employee has an issue. Need to better support well being of employees and structured advancement for all that want it, not just favorites.

title: I worked at Simon for five years.
pros: Simon is an international genius in the real estate world but not in its home-grown back yard. Nice building, altho shoddily constructed; one might expect more of this giant. Charitable contributions (if that they are) are amazing.
cons: Way too little (i.e., none) training, support and mentoring; ugly management, always changing; pitiful IT systems.

title: Company is respected in the industry, but a TERRIBLE place to work - Do yourself a favor and DON'T accept an offer!
pros: -Not really any pros worth noting, but I will try - nice office space in Indy -They make other companies look good when recruiters and friends start calling for you to come work for them
cons: -Management by Fear. This starts with the CEO who is very degrading and has bad manners with employees. Yells, curses, yells more, curses more, tells you are stupid..... -Communication from management at all levels is non-existent -Very secretive culture -IT is terrible. They only upgraded to Windows 7 when XP was not serviced any longer. Was still using Office 2003 in 2014. -Many employees feel overworked and under compensated -Employees are definitely undervalued and you work in a toxic environment -Very little room for development & growth for most -Company values are just for show -HR is unresponsive and inefficient, so don't bother asking for help -No work/life balance -There is no development or training for middle management...so inevitably you end up with inept, untrained management and 30% of middle management should never have been promoted from their staff positions -You can build a much more fulfilling career elsewhere. Do your self a favor and don't accept an offer. Find a company that has good stated values and actually cares to uphold them.....RUN WHILE YOU STILL CAN

title: Marketing Administrator
pros: Looking back, the only "pros" from this job was the co-workers and friends that I made myself...but had NOTHING to do with Simon Property Group (SPG) When recruiters see SPG on applicant's resumes, they already know how hard you work. Working for Simon Property Group is for you, if you like getting underpaid, emotionally-exhausted, and undervalued.
cons: This is literally the worst job I've ever had. You're underpaid for an ridiculous amount of work and there's no such thing as a "team-culture." Credit is never due to the person who actually does the work and also, your regional marketing/sales staff will quickly take credit for your hard work. As soon as relationships are built and $$$ is negotiated, someone "higher" than you will want to take credit for their bonuses. There were countless times, I've seen this happen to my direct reports. Absolutely ridiculous. Field employees (Employees working at the mall themselves) are literally treated like dirt-- at no point are the field employee's "thanked" for their hard work. Not even a generic Christmas e-card, cheap giveaway, nothing. Vacations are "frozen" during November and December and you're expected to work weekends at least once a month. Asking to take vacations are always a hassle and an inconvenience to your direct reports. Bonus? If you're paid hourly, you won't get one. Paid Salary? Taxes alone will take more than half of what you've already earned since the company doesn't include it in your regular salary. Want to move up "with the fortune 500 company?" Good luck, unless you're working in HQ or you have an "in" with the field property management. SPG will make their employees feel like they have a chance to move up, but honestly, consider yourself lucky if you move up one pay grade higher at least once every 5+ years. Also, kiss these goodbye: your earned PTO when you resign, and don't ever expect a huge tax return during tax season.

title: Good Group
pros: Worked here for the summer as a customer service representative. Competitive pay and nice working facility. New shopping center led to high morale.
cons: My coworkers were unreliable and there was heavy turnover on the staff. Customers were disrespectful and you were often understaffed at peak times.

title: Marketing Admin
pros: Benefits and that's about it
cons: Ridiculously stressful and overwhelming amount of work for the little you get paid. There is 0 training and when you get asked to do something that you've never been trained on, basically everything, and it takes you a while to do it than you get punished for it. You could give this job your all and it still wouldn't be enough. No one will ever appreciate the amount of hard work you do. I wouldn't wish this job upon anyone, it will make you miserable and run you into the ground.

title: Do not apply
pros: Nothing good to say as of today
cons: One bad apple can ruin an entire great team!! HR needs to know what is going on in field! Big price to pay if they do not! Total ignorance and harassment in 2018 is no joke. Wake up!

title: Relatively Good in a Tough Business
pros: Relative stability within the unstable mall business, opportunity for well-rounded marketing experience, very rewarding at times, fun
cons: Lots of evenings and weekends, expected to be available 24/7, feels like shortsighted management - everything about the bottom line and making the most money possible right now - didn't used to be like this

title: Woodbury Commons
pros: Having employment Discount for whatever store you work at
cons: Long lines at the food court Restricted parking Rude tourists

title: Don't accept the position
pros: The only pro is that you will have a steady job, but not because they furlough to save a few dollars.
cons: Don't accept the job and leave the one you are in. I read the reviews and ignored them. This company is Fortune 500 in name only. it acts as a mom-and-pop shop under the guise of Fortune 500. The work environment is toxic, there is no room for improvement. Ceilings everywhere. There are people working in this company for 30 years, they won't change. And the company reacts stupidly to everything. Instead of leading the industry, they follow trends for 2 minutes. The first sign of trouble in COVID, they laid off the Development department followed by furloughing everyone from the Marketing team. Anyone making money over 120K was forced into a 10% cut but later on, they were retroactively paid back. Meanwhile, the folks including myself from the Marketing department didn't get anything. We lost our income. BTW this happened in March. Note April of 2020 or May but March. The GM's are toxic, no one checks on the property. My property GM hires their relatives to do some of the work and accepts favours from contractors but the company does not know this. They send an audit, but GMs do the audit so.... Then HR, not helpful. HR matters are never properly addressed. There are no follow-ups. They launch an investigation but don't actually do anything. No one cares about you, if you have great ideas, your GMs will take credit and never give you due credit. They are all about looking good to Denise, the RVP. Denise on the other hand bullies her GMs. She yells and screams at them. I feel for all the GMs. That woman is nasty, emotional and needs HR to address things but HR, how dare they touch an RVP. It becomes about we have to work as a team and how Denise is producing numbers. All Denise does is keep people on the tightest leash. There are no commissions for the team. Your prizes are to play BINGO and get a COOZIE or a Wristlet if you make a 100,000 deal. Denise really loves this game. Let's talk about SAFETY - you were allowed to work from home for a short period (1month). Now you are not allowed. We are NOT vaccinated and the team comes to a MALL environment but like every sensible company, you are not even given the option of working from home. Marketing doe NOT need to be at the mall. I can go on and on but trust me if you are coming from a well-established company or a job, don't do it no matter how bad the situation is over there. This company is terrrible.

title: One of the best in the industry.
pros: Simon is an amazing company. There is tenure, leadership and innovation. I have had a long career with the company and have learned a great deal about the industry and been able to advance my career. The teams at Simon are one of the best benefits. The expectations are aggressive but there is great reward in achievement.
cons: Not a lot of work/ life balance.

title: Good Job
pros: - The work is fun if you like working with marketing materials and retail stores. - Getting to be creative with window displays was great! - Making friends with the retailers is a lot of fun! - Great events - Great co-workers
cons: - Management likes you to work during holidays even though you are not in management. - You do not get paid to do managerial tasks.

title: Big company, big responsibilities, but little control over destiny
pros: Solid and secure company, benefits are great, annual bonuses fair, top brands
cons: Micromanagement of properties, inability to affect change, limited and shrinking operational budgets, low base pay in comparison for similar responsibilities, top down management, layers of reporting - often overlapping

title: Director of Marketing and Business Development
pros: It's a job with a paycheck. The fact that you can get a full bonus does not reflect what your review might say. That is, if you actually get one. New ways of doing things are not encouraged. If you get along with the Mall Manager it can be okay, if not, watch your back.
cons: This company is well run when it comes to Wall Street. When it comes to the company culture the company is very poorly run. Management at the Corporate level believes in "Management by Intimidation". In addition, nepotism is rampant with children/cousins of top management in positions they would never get on their own skills. The "Field"(malls) tries to do the best, but this is where the company cuts back. So rather than cut fat at the Corporate level, the people in the Field are expected to carry out plans made by Corporate (who have never worked in the Field) with minimal staff. People are working 12 hours a day usually 6 days a week. You're always catching up with no time to really plan ahead. People who are handling a lot of money in Guest Services and are the first people customers meet are paid just above minimum wage. That's just wrong and inviting problems.

title: Office Administrator
pros: Close to home and local shopping (other than the property itself)
cons: The culture and mentality of this company is well known. They are management heavy, and will make scape goats out of the hourly employees. While the Office Administrator works "with" management, they are not management. While they support the managers, they are not privy to the bonuses and perks management gets, yet without the support of the OA, there would be no bonuses. Employee beware. Expectations are high and unrealistic; rewards and recognition minimal. Everyone is out for themselves and will throw you under the bus should it suit them. Beware of the moles - no one is your friend so watch your back. This is a great job for someone who has eyes in the back of their head so they can constantly see who is gunning for them.

title: Great Starting Point
pros: - Great place to learn more about the industry and grow network - International company that gives you options to move around - Offers opportunity to grow community relationships
cons: - Training isn't the first priority in many settings - Company tends to move around employees and not refill positions - Working in smaller teams can be beneficial, but in many cases can cause employees to feel more pressure and overlapping job duties

title: Very pleasant and educating.
pros: Good balance between work and life. Some opportunities for growth. Good place to learn sales techniques you can transfer to other professions.
cons: Communicating with upper management can sometime be difficult. Pay is satisfactory. Position involves working weekends and longer hours during the holiday season.

title: The Most Cut-Throat Environment Ever
pros: Insurance Benefits, Bonus, nothing else
cons: Cut-Throat Environment, Bad-Management, Poor Work-Life Balance, Must work on Holidays and Weekends, Low Pay, No Room for Growth, Management only cares about their bonuses. My Manager had no regard for my personal life as she would call me on my days off and expect me to be readily available at all times. Even on days when I would call out sick, she would text and call. I would have to work up to 60 hours per week and only get paid for 40 hours. The company expects you to work a minimum of 50+ hours and only pay you for 40 hours. The majority of Managers micro-manage as this is part of the company culture. The company "Simonizes" its staff into robots who are constantly available who must show up to work even during inclement weather, like blizzards and hurricanes. They expect you to multi-task at the speed of light or you are not efficient enough. Must work long, hard hours on weekends and especially Holidays. I became physically and mentally burned out along with some of my colleagues. There were times when I had no coverage to even use the restroom. I observed racist and elitist comments and attitudes toward minorities and disabled employees. Corporate Office would send email updates and implement new programs every day and require you to get accustomed to the ever-changing environment. Employees walk around the office looking like slobs with no makeup on or business attire due to the high stress the company puts them through. Most employees who remain become brainwashed into company culture and like vultures wait for their turn to move to the next position. One cannot even eat lunch in peace because there was always something that needed to be done at that precise moment. Most Guest Services Mangers do not last a year and when they do, it is because these people have families and must keep their jobs and cannot afford to lose their benefits. This position is not highly respected. If you are a GSM you are basically everyone's doormat and they expect you to accept this as normal. The Corporate Office is also very disorganized in terms of program implementation and realistic expectations. Minimal resources are allocated and yet one must make miracles. Simon Property Group is the absolute worst company I have ever worked for and would not recommend this company to my worst enemy.

title: Unrealistic Expectations in an Unprofessional Environment
pros: -Benefits were decent, 401k match was good. -The handful of genuine people I built relationships with along the way and a select few people will try and help you to succeed. -Ability to move up if you are willing to work hard ( it worked for me)
cons: I worked at multiple properties and carried multiple positions during my employment. Each one got worse and worse- however the underlying issues are all the same. Lack of competency and caring from field level management and lack of concern from VPs makes it a very frustrating environment. Veteran employees point fingers while the people underneath them are worked to death for a fraction of the pay and essentially no training. It is routine to leave crucial positions open for months in order to save money, but managers wont step up to absorb any of the additional responsibilities. It all boils down to the bottom line and the managers bonuses. At my last mall- my direct supervisor was immature, inappropriate and the way i was treated eventually became intolerable and borderline abusive. The majority of my departments workload fell on my shoulders and I was expected to be available to work no matter what day or time to get it all done. There were times I worked 7 days a week and wasn’t allowed to take comp time or it would be promised and revoked. I was told I couldn’t take vacation days that had been approved 6 months in advance for no reason and was routinely guilted into working nights and weekends at the last minute. Having prior commitments was unacceptable- if I was unable to be available at the drop of a hat I was told "this is not the job for you." I was yelled by my manager in front of another co-worker during an event and was never given an apology. When I addressed it directly I was told if you're upset about it then you clearly cant handle it and "this is not the job for you." Addressing issues with your HR wasn’t an option as the only outcome will be a target on your back. They are not there for the protection of employees, they are there to defend management- issues are buried and nothing remains confidential. Higher ups knew what was happening and allowed it continue because after so many years this became the norm. I eventually became burned out and quit due to the unrealistic expectations. The lack of concern from anyone above me was disheartening. The expectations of many positions were unrealistic - not just mine. They push you until you crack, then treat you as if you are weak. The unprofessional culture was often perpetuated by management. Some VPs are aware of unacceptable behaviors going on and instead of addressing them- they talk about them among mall teams- almost deeming them acceptable as they became a running joke. Certain VPs were the number one source of gossip. They were the first to blame you for things your supervisor was responsible for and we’re just blatantly disrespectful. When i finally quit it was hardly acknowledged by anyone except the VP who essentially said she’d do me a favor and let me stay.

title: Great learning experience
